section.title: Translate PDF files or files in formats not recognized by OmegaT
section.para: Since the PDF format is designed for layout rather than handling text, translating PDF files a thorny issue. The text formatting information in such files cannot be used by OmegaT to create target files. Consequently, PDF files are handled as plain text files both for reading the source and creating the translation.
You have a few options if you need to reproduce the format (and other visual elements such as drawings) in the final translation.

listitem.para: Use the default OmegaT PDF input filter to translate the document to a plain text file, and manually recreate the formatting after loading that text in a suitable application.
Use the Iceni Infix filter. See Howto - Translating PDF files with Iceni Infix and OmegaT.
Import the source file in LibreOffice Draw, save it as an ODG file, translate it, and export the final version to PDF if necessary.
Convert the PDF to another suitable file format from Adobe Acrobat, if available, or using third-party tools. After the translation is complete, convert the final version to PDF.

note.para: The above information assumes the PDF file contains a text layer. If you have a PDF file consisting of scanned pages (sometimes called a "dead" PDF), you will first have to need to use an optical character recognition (OCR) program to convert the pages into machine-readable text that can be handled by OmegaT.

section.title: Files in a formats not supported by OmegaT
section.para: You will have to convert files for which OmegaT does not have a filter to a supported format to translate them in OmegaT.

The original application, or a third-party tool, can often perform such conversions. You will probably also have to convert the translated files back to the original format. For example, if you have received a document in the outdated Microsoft Word .doc format, which is not supported by OmegaT, you can follow the steps below to perform a round trip for the translation.

listitem.para: Load the file in Word (2007 or later), LibreOffice, or other modern application that can read .doc files.
Save the file in .docx or .odt format.
Translate the file and generate the target .docx or .odt document.
After you have proofread everything, load the target file in the application you used for the initial conversion.
Save the file back into the .doc format.

section.para: The quality of the formatting of the translated file will depend on the quality of the round-trip conversion. Investigate the various available options to choose the best one for your specific situation. Check the OmegaT home page for an up-to-date listing of auxiliary tools.
